issue.title: Fixes #384 - JUnit rule provides stubbing hint to help debugging tests

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
Recreated the branch / recreated the PR. This is ready, I want to improve the docs (MockitoHint) before merging.

See the use case in issue #384 

I'm growing the StubbingListener and getting JUnit rule take advantage of it to report hints to the user that hopefully help debugging tests.

issue.title: Removing mockingDetails API from Mockito

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
After some exchange with other member of the community, code such as 

``` java
Mockito.mockingDetails(someObject).isMock();
Mockito.mockingDetails(someObject).isSpy();
```

It looks wrong ; Mockito is the entry point for user friendly usage from within the test. Inspecting mocks looks wrong when it's a normal _user_.

However I know framework developers may need to inspect mocks. Let's keep the `MockingDetails` type but instantiate it from another static factory method.

The drawback is the removal of this API for current users. Maybe we can mark `Mockito.mockingDetails(..)` deprecated in 1.9.x and remove it in 2.0.0

issue.title: Deprecate Mockito.debug().printInvocations() API

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
I'm trying to get closure on awkward Mockito.debug().printInvocations() API. The API is semi-internal, package-protected and deprecated :) This API is simply unfinished (just like the verbose JUnit runner was unfinished until recently).

Options for Mockito.debug().printInvocations()
1. delete this API without replacement, wait for users feedback if they need it.
2. move to MockingDetails.printInvocations() and make public (already planned in #543)
3. move to Mockito.framework().printInvocations() and make public
4. option 2) + some composite mocking details API so that we can print invocations across multiple mocks
5. ?

My thinking:

1) Tempting, we already have 'verbose mode'. Still, it feels the feature is useful and is mentioned on SO (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11802088/how-do-i-enable-mockito-debug-messages). I don't think users will request this feature even if it is useful because they can use existing API and hack up a solution.
2) I like it. However, it is not as powerful because usually we want to investigate the behavior / stubbing of multiple mocks. MockingDetails only covers a single mock. Original printInvocations() method neatly shows interactions/stubbings in order across multiple mock objects.
3) Mockito.framework() already exists so we could use it. However, it feels that printing invocations is not really for framework integrators so I don't think it is a good place for this API.
4) Option (2) with the multi-mock feature. I kinda like it. Example how it could work:

Mockito.mockingDetails(mock).isMock();
Mockito.mockingDetails(mock).getInvocations();
Mockito.mockingDetails(mock).printInvocations();

~~Mockito.mockingDetails(mock, mock2, mock3).isMock();~~
Mockito.mockingDetails(mock, mock2, mock3).getInvocations();
Mockito.mockingDetails(mock, mock2, mock3).printInvocations();

Signatures:

public MockingDetails mockingDetails(Object mock); //existing
public CompositeMockingDetails mockingDetails(Object ... mocks); //new
MockingDetails extends CompositeMockingDetails //API consistency

CompositeMockingDetails //new interface
CompositeMockingDetails.getInvocations()
CompositeMockingDetails.printInvocations()
CompositeMockingDetails.getStubbings() //see #542

Your thoughts?

body: Created a preview PR for this feature: #676
I'm about to finish off this feature and roll out 2.2.0. This way, we avoid showing 2.2.0-beta.

Um I do not think that was the plan, given our milestone 2.2.0. There are other issues we want to fix in 2.2.0. Let's not publish the release until we have fixed these issues. See https://github.com/mockito/mockito/milestone/3 Most of these issues have a PR already open
Let's adjust the plans. Including multiple changes/features into single compatible version is an anti-pattern.

I have to disagree. We published 2.1 less than a week ago, releasing 2.2.0 now would be way too soon. Moreover, we have discussed the feature set for 2.2.0 targeting to improve the ArgumentCaptor. Releasing a minor version with this 1 new api seems redundant, annoying on the user site and will result in an overload of minor version upgrades. Therefore I would like to stick to our plan and include this extra api in to 2.2.0.

The reason we need to release 2.2.0 is to remove 2.2.0-beta version from being the latest in central.

I'm with you that it feels too small feature for minor version. However, it solves the problem above and it is consistent with semantic versioning :)

Mockito release process (continuous delivery) does not include multiple features in a single version, with the exception for major version releases. I consider the 2.2.0 milestone as rough plan for what's after 2.1.0 but not a feature set to include in a specific version. Every new feature / change will ship a separate version, like 2.2.1, 2.2.2, etc.

> The reason we need to release 2.2.0 is to remove 2.2.0-beta version from being the latest in central.

I don't agree. We don't have to release a new version just not see 2.2.0-beta.1.

I think betas is a very good thing, albeit maybe not on central, or as a snapshot, whatever. And betas are a good thing for that, I still think they could stay on bintray.

> I consider the 2.2.0 milestone as rough plan for what's after 2.1.0 but not a feature set to include in a specific version.

You may consider that, but that is clearly not the intended when I gathered these item togetber as a milestone.

Users may want incremental update on a website but developers don't like it when it's about libraries. Let's not rebrand beta release without the beta tag.

There is a wiki page that describes current release model of Mockito. I thought that you wrote this wiki yourself :)

C'mon @bric3, accept continuous delivery and move on. Let's innovate, learn and win rather than stick to the old ways!

It was written to help what's happening on this front. It doesn't mean I'm fully sold to it. I do like the continuous delivery of betas or maintenance rereleased really do! But I'm not comfortable to release just every change happening on `release/2.x` or `master`.

Also the 2.2 is a continuation of what couldn't be done in 2.1, there's some interesting feedback from the community to wait for, there's some refactoring on captors that also may need some feedback, etc. 

> Let's innovate, learn and win rather than stick to the old ways!

This is not mutually exclusive. Also the old ways aren't always bad. But in this case there's middle ground to find. 

On stackoverflow some were confused about incremental releases, same for answering this is an additional step to get the specific version that brought this change.

issue.body: Added new API. For motivation, see #542
